Tabs & Accordion

Main Demo Layout Switcher

Pure CSS Interactive Components

Tabs and accordions without JavaScript. Uses native HTML features and CSS :checked pseudo-class for state management.

  • Radio buttons for exclusive tab selection
  • Native <details> with name attribute for exclusive accordion
  • CSS animations for smooth transitions
  • Fully keyboard accessible

Horizontal Tabs

Radio button pattern with sibling combinator for panel switching.

How It Works

The tabs use hidden radio inputs combined with the CSS :checked pseudo-class. When a radio button is checked, we use the general sibling combinator (~) to show the corresponding panel and style the active tab label.

This technique works because radio buttons with the same name attribute maintain exclusive selection natively in HTML.

Features

  • Zero JavaScript - Pure HTML and CSS solution
  • Accessible - Keyboard navigation works natively
  • Animated - Smooth fade-in transitions
  • Themeable - Inherits design tokens automatically
  • Responsive - Adapts to container width

HTML Structure

<div class="tabs">
  <input type="radio" name="tabs" id="tab1" checked>
  <input type="radio" name="tabs" id="tab2">

  <nav class="tab-nav">
    <label for="tab1">Tab 1</label>
    <label for="tab2">Tab 2</label>
  </nav>

  <section class="tab-panel" data-tab="1">...</section>
  <section class="tab-panel" data-tab="2">...</section>
</div>

CSS Pattern

/* Hide all panels by default */
.tab-panel {
  display: none;
}

/* Show panel when corresponding radio is checked */
#tab1:checked ~ .tab-panel[data-tab="1"],
#tab2:checked ~ .tab-panel[data-tab="2"] {
  display: block;
}

/* Style active tab label */
#tab1:checked ~ .tab-nav label[for="tab1"],
#tab2:checked ~ .tab-nav label[for="tab2"] {
  color: var(--color-primary);
  border-color: var(--color-primary);
}

Use Cases

This pattern is ideal for:

  • Settings pages with categorized options
  • Product pages with description/specs/reviews tabs
  • Documentation with multiple sections
  • Any content that benefits from progressive disclosure

For more complex interactions (dynamic content loading, URL routing), consider adding progressive enhancement with JavaScript.

Accordion

Native <details> element with exclusive behavior via the name attribute.

What is the Vanilla Breeze Grid System?

The Grid Identity System automatically assigns grid areas to semantic HTML elements. Instead of adding classes, elements like <header>, <nav>, <main>, and <footer> get their grid placement from their identity in the DOM.

This means you can switch between layouts just by changing the data-layout attribute on the body element.

How does the token architecture work?

The design token system uses three layers:

  • Primitives - Raw values like colors, spacing, and typography scales
  • Semantic - Contextual meanings like --color-primary or --gap-lg
  • Component - Specific usage like --button-padding-x

Themes override semantic tokens to create dramatic visual transformations while keeping component behavior consistent.

Is this accessible?

Yes! The <details> and <summary> elements are natively accessible:

  • Keyboard navigation works out of the box (Enter/Space to toggle)
  • Screen readers announce the expanded/collapsed state
  • Focus management is handled by the browser

The name attribute (added in 2024) enables exclusive accordion behavior natively.

What browsers support this?

The exclusive accordion (name attribute on <details>) is supported in:

  • Chrome 120+ (December 2023)
  • Firefox 130+ (August 2024)
  • Safari 17.2+ (December 2023)

In older browsers, the accordion still works but allows multiple panels to be open simultaneously.

Vertical Tabs

Same pattern, different layout using CSS Grid.

Getting Started

To use the Vanilla Breeze system, include the three core CSS files:

<link rel="stylesheet" href="vanilla-breeze-tokens.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="vanilla-breeze-grid.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="vanilla-breeze-base.css">

Then add a theme file and set data-theme and data-layout attributes on your body element.

Configuration

Customize the system by overriding CSS custom properties. The token system allows granular control at each layer:

:root {
  /* Override primitives */
  --blue-500: oklch(55% 0.2 240);

  /* Override semantic */
  --color-primary: var(--blue-500);

  /* Override component */
  --button-radius: var(--radius-full);
}

Advanced Usage

For advanced customization, you can create your own theme file following the pattern in the theme files. Use the @layer theme directive to ensure proper cascade ordering.

Container queries and the :has() selector enable component-level responsive behavior without JavaScript.

Non-Exclusive Accordion

Without the name attribute, multiple panels can be open simultaneously.

Panel One (can be open with others)

This panel doesn't have a name attribute, so it operates independently. Multiple panels can be open at the same time.

Panel Two (can be open with others)

Open this panel while Panel One is open. Both will stay visible. This is the default behavior of <details> elements.

Panel Three (can be open with others)

All three panels can be open simultaneously. Use this pattern when content isn't mutually exclusive and users might want to compare sections.
